Award.AwardTitle: LTREB: Long-Term Studies of Seedling and Small Sapling Community Dynamics in a Neotropical Forest
Award.AbstractNarration: This grant supports a continuation of a long-term study of a tropical rain forest and how it is responding to climate change. The forest is in the Panama Canal on Barro Colorado Island (BCI), a biological reserve managed by the Smithsonian and one of the botanically and ecologically best known tropical forests in the world. The grant is to study germination and survival of seedlings, stages of tree life histories that are most sensitive to climate. Large changes in seasonal and annual rainfall patterns are predicted in the tropics due to increasing atmospheric CO2, which may cause major changes in the tree species composition and turnover rates of tropical forests. Seedlings are early warning systems because of their drought sensitivity. Results of this project should be practically beneficial in forecasting how tropical rain forests will respond to climate change. The study also adds to basic understanding of how tropical rain forests work and why they have so many tree species. The subject research plot, five football fields in size, has twice the tree species found in all of North America north of Mexico. This project will test the hypothesis that seedling fluctuations let more species coexist by giving rare species a competitive edge in years when common species fail to reproduce. Prior support has resulted in the training of many U.S. students in tropical botany and ecology (over 200 undergraduate and graduate trainees since 1980, including 7 Ph.D.'s and 4 Master's students). Students, colleagues, and PIs associated with this project have already published more than 100 papers and 3 books based on data from this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For this project, we monitored seedlings of 400+ tropical tree, shrub and liana species on an annual basis to amass a large database on seedling growth and survival in the tropical forest of Barro Colorado Island, Panama. These data were used to test theories concerning how so many species can coexist in tropical forests. The data revealed that species are able to coexist because the probability of a seedling surviving declines when it is surrounded by other seedlings of its own species, which prevents any one species from becoming dominant. In addition, our data revealed that within and between year variation in rainfall, specifically during dry periods, is an important driver of seedling survival.

The project resulted in the training of dozens of students and early career biologists, providing valuable field experience in a tropical forest. In addition, the project generated a large data set that has been used by many other researchers. Results from the project have been featured in recent text books and have been shared with visiting students and tourists at our research site.  Results from this study will help scientists predict how tropical tree species will respond to changing climate and will be useful in designing plantations and restoration and reforestation strategies.
